awd_titl_txt: AccessINCLUDES: Linking the knowledge and results of NSF disability-related projects and projects within the NSF INCLUDES National Network
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Washington's DO-IT (Disabilities, Opportunities, Internetworking, and Technology) Center, which has decades of experience in designing welcoming, accessible, and usable courses, research, websites, videos, and electronic documents, leads the AccessINCLUDES project. AccessINCLUDES addresses the broadening participation challenge that individuals with disabilities are underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. AccessINCLUDES brings the work of the NSF INCLUDES National Network together with the work of DO-IT to address the intersection of identity with an emphasis on disability-related issues. AccessINCLUDES links to the NSF INCLUDES Network by sharing knowledge and results from NSF disability-focused projects and their network organizations to better prepare the NSF INCLUDES National Network to: 1. address disability-related issues in their research (e.g., design interventions to be accessible; recruit, support, and report outcomes for participants with disabilities); 2. make meetings, trainings, courses, and other project activities welcoming and accessible to individuals with disabilities; 3. design project resources and products to be accessible to individuals with disabilities; and 4. develop durable, new collaborations between multiple stakeholders and organizations that lead to future innovative projects and resources that are inclusive of individuals with disabilities. Ultimately, including more individuals with disabilities in STEM fields broadens participation and enhances these fields with their unique perspectives and expertise.

Individuals with disabilities inform all aspects of the project. Participants include (1) current and future NSF INCLUDES Design and Development Launch Projects, Alliances, and the Coordination Hub, and (2) disability-focused broadening participation. All project activities support and disseminate outcomes from three conferences, one two-day on-site and two half-day webinars, all designed to be accessible to individuals with disabilities. Conference participants engage in an online community of practice focused on the project goal and objectives and conference development. In the conferences AccessINCLUDES participants, informed by research and practice with respect to broadening participation; STEM, disabilities, change management, and organizational development, advance knowledge relevant to increasing the success of individuals with disabilities through research, instruction, activities, and products of NSF INCLUDES projects. Resources collected and developed and the two dissemination webinars are tailored to the needs of the NSF INCLUDES National Network, so that they have lasting value for making Network projects more inclusive of individuals with disabilities. The project ensures long-term impact by building on two associations, NSF INCLUDES projects and NSF-funded disability-focused projects, and creating durable relationships among projects that enhance the infrastructure for STEM broadening participation research and practice; increasing the participation of people with disabilities in STEM; and disseminating transformational research and practice to enhance understanding and promote replication and impact in the NSF INCLUDES National Network and other STEM and disability-focused organizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The University of Washington (UW) received "Conference" funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF) to support DCL: NSF INCLUDES: Accessible INCLUDES National Network, in short "AccessINCLUDES." This proposal responded to the first conference objective listed in NSF's Dear Colleague Letter (NSF 17-111), by linking "to the NSF INCLUDES National Network the knowledge and results from the NSF broadening participation portfolio of programs and projects...and encourage new opportunities for collaboration across the network."

The overarching goal of AccessINCLUDES was to advance knowledge about how STEM researchers and practitioners can engage all segments of the population in their work, including individuals with disabilities. To achieve this goal AccessINCLUDES linked to the NSF INCLUDES Network in order to make the INCLUDES Network - Design and Development Launch Pilots (DDLPs), Alliances, and Hub - better prepared to

  • address disability-related issues in their research (e.g., design interventions to be accessible; recruit, support, and report outcomes for participants with disabilities);
  • make meetings, trainings, courses, and other project activities welcoming and accessible to individuals with disabilities;
  • design project resources and products to be accessible to individuals with disabilities; and
  • develop durable, new collaborations between multiple stakeholders and organizations that lead to future innovative projects and resources that are inclusive of individuals with disabilities.

Activities designed to meet these objectives included one two-day on-site and two half-day online conferences, which we called capacity building institutes (CBIs), supported with an online community of practice (CoP). AccessINCLUDES embraced a multi-faceted framework of systemic change, engagement, and inclusion in STEM. AccessINCLUDES views disability as an aspect of diversity. AccessINCLUDES encouraged INCLUDES projects to strive for systemic change to address multiple issues relevant to individuals with diverse characteristics. All project activities were designed to broaden participation as we sought to improve the knowledge and skills of INCLUDES projects regarding addressing disability-related issues in their research, designing accessible project materials, meetings, course, websites, etc., and developing collaborations that result in new projects resources that are accessible.

Project participants included (1) INCLUDES Design and Development Launch Pilots (DDLPs), Alliances, and the Coordination Hub, and (2) RDE and other disability-focused broadening participation projects.

AccessINCLUDES participants - informed by research and practice with respect to broadening participation, STEM, disabilities, change management, and organizational development - advanced knowledge relevant to increasing the success of individuals with disabilities through research, instruction, activities, and products of INCLUDES projects. Much of this work was done through the incorporation of universal design, which can be a course of its own, something taught through cornerstone or capstone projects, or blended into all design courses in the curriculum. Staff and faculty from a variety of STEM disciplines can learn more about universal design (UD), possible accommodations, working with students with disabilities in general and much more through AccessINCLUDES project products:

  • Proceedings from each CBI that includes content that can guide others interested in pursuing similar goals.
  • The AccessINCLUDES website, https://www.washington.edu/doit/programs/accessincludes, shares resources for students, educators, and others interested in increasing the participation of people with disabilities in projects and activities.
  • The AccessINCLUDES searchable Knowledge Base, an electronic tool that engages collaborators in drafting, reviewing, editing, approving, and posting questions and answers, case studies, and promising practices. Feedback from users indicates that the Knowledge Base is a catalyst and resource for educators, service providers, students, and employers.

Dissemination of project materials

The project (1) communicated research findings from the science of broadening participation research community (in this case, relative to the inclusion of individuals with disabilities) to the NSF INCLUDES National Network and (2) provided a platform for projects to discover common interests and develop future collaborations. The collaborative and engaging nature of the CBIs and CoP allowed more experienced projects to increase their capacity for leadership while building on-ramps for new organizations and stakeholders as the National Network expanded.

The project website (https://www.washington.edu/doit/programs/accessincludes) provides not only an overview of the project but also shares resources for stakeholders interested in increasing the participation of people with disabilities in projects within the INCLUDES Network. It features a Searchable Knowledge Base of Q&As, case studies, and promising practices, proceedings from the CBI and resource materials such as brochures and videos.

Broader Impacts from AccessINCLUDES

AccessINCLUDES ensured long-term impact by building on two associations - INCLUDES projects and NSF-funded disability-focused projects - and creating durable relationships among projects that enhance the infrastructure for STEM broadening participation research and practice; increasing the participation of people with disabilities in STEM; and disseminating transformational research and practice to enhance understanding and promote replication and impact in the INCLUDES National Network and other STEM and disability-focused organizations. As funding has ended, the DO-IT Center will continue to share project outcomes and products through its Knowledge Base, publications, and videos and at conferences attended as part of future projects; the CoP will also be supported. 

 


Last Modified: 04/13/2023
Modified by: Sheryl Burgstahler
